Title: Ghosts of Consumption (for Piet M.)
Creator: Pam Longobardi
Material: Found ocean plastic from Hawaii, Alaska, Greece, Costa Rica, Italy, and the Gulf of Mexico
Location: Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art
Creditline: Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, Bentonville, Arkansas, 2021.43
Description: A sculptural installation by Pam Longobardi that addresses plastic pollution, global consumption, and environmental loss. Constructed from discarded plastic debris collected from oceans and shorelines, the work assembles colorful fragments into a chaotic yet deliberate composition. The piece evokes the lingering “ghosts” of consumer culture—objects designed for convenience that outlive their usefulness and return as environmental threats. By transforming waste into art, Longobardi reveals how plastics migrate across borders and ecosystems, implicating global systems of production and consumption.

Title: Toxic Evolution
Creator: Alvaro Soler-Arpa
Material: Different animal bones, wire and plastic waste
Description: The works imagine a near future in which animal life has been radically altered by human-made pollution and genetic contamination. Presented through a false scientific format, the work depicts elegant yet disturbing hybrid creatures whose mutations—caused by toxicity, transgenics, and environmental waste—challenge the natural rhythms of evolution and geological time. These fictitious beings symbolize the consequences of humanity’s irresponsible impact on nature.

Title: Bovine Divine
Creator: Siddhartha Kararwal
Visualtags: religion, politics, freedom of speech, freedom of expression
Description: The 4-pound Styrofoam cow was created to hghlight the plight of abandoned cows left to die on the streets. The animals considered holy often succumbed after consuming plastic from garbage dumps. The work was taken down after being deemed religiously offensive..

Title: Creatives Against #CAA
Creator: Kadak Collective
Description: An online archive containing various creative and informational material, including printable files,protest posters, zines, images, and  infographics explaining the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC).The CAA act along with NRC was critiqued as an attempt to deny citizenship based on religion and disenfranchise Indian Muslims.

Title: Anti-CAA Murals
Creator: Simeen Anjum
Description: Simeen Anjum, a fine art student at Jamia Millia Islamia and other artists came to represent the artistic expression of political dissent through the creation of murals and graffiti in public spaces. The anti-CAA and NRC movement mobilized the public at the grassroots level and art functioned as a powerful tool for resistance.

Title: Shackville
Creator: Rhodes Must Fall Movement
Description: A protest installation constructed in 2016 by Rhodes Must Fall student activists at the University of Cape Town (UCT) to draw attention to severe campus housing shortages and unequal living conditions. The structure was a makeshift shack built from corrugated metal, wood, and other scavenged materials, deliberately resembling informal housing found in South African townships. Placed prominently on campus, the shack functioned as both a symbol and an intervention, confronting the university community with the material realities faced by many Black and working-class students who were excluded from adequate accommodation. By inserting an informal dwelling into an elite academic space, the protest highlighted the persistence of structural inequality, spatial injustice, and the unfinished business of decolonization in post-apartheid South Africa.

Title: The Son of a Migrant from Syria
Creator: Bansky
Description: A mural by Banksy painted in Calais, France, near the “Jungle” refugee camp that foregrounds Apple founder Steve Jobs’s immigrant background and significant contributions to his host country, positioning the work as a critique of the escalating anti-immigrant rhetoric across Europe and the United States. The work reframes migrants as innovators, contributors and figures of potential and humanity,

Title: Love Is In The Air, Flower Thrower
Creator: Bansky
Description: This is a 2003 mural by Banksy, originally painted in Jerusalem. The image depicts a masked protester, dressed like a rioter and caught mid-throw, but instead of a weapon he hurls a bouquet of brightly colored flowers. The work juxtaposes violence and aggression against peace and hope.

Title: Slave Labor
Creator: Bansky
Description:
Also known as Bunting Boy, the 2012 mural by the anonymous street artist Banksy, was originally painted on the side of a shop in Wood Green, London. The work shows a young child hunched over a sewing machine, producing a string of Union Jack bunting.
The image is a sharp critique of exploitative labor practices, particularly child labor and sweatshop production linked to Western consumer culture.

Title: Do Women still have to be naked to get into the MET Museum
Creator: Guerilla Girls
Description:
The Guerrilla Girls are an anonymous feminist activist art collective founded in 1985 in New York. Their work exposes sexism, racism, and power imbalances in the art world and broader culture, especially within museums, galleries, Hollywood, and politics.
They are best known for bold posters, billboards, and public interventions that combine statistics, sharp humor, and graphic design. Using a visual style influenced by advertising — high-contrast colors, large type, and punchy slogans — they present hard data about the underrepresentation of women and artists of color. One of their most famous posters asks: “Do women have to be naked to get into the Met. Museum?” pairing the question with a statistic about how few women artists are shown compared to how many nude female bodies appear in the collection. The collective members wear gorilla masks and adopt the names of deceased women artists to maintain anonymity. This shifts attention away from individual authorship and toward systemic critique, while also protecting members from professional backlash

Title: Q: And Babies? A: And Babies
Creator: Irving Petlin, Jon Hendricks, Frazier Dougherty, The Artists' Poster Committee of the Art Workers' Coalition, Original photograph of the My Lai massacre by R. L. Haeberle
Creditline: © The Artists' Poster Committee of the Art Workers' Coalition
Description: The work is an anti-Vietnam war poster created by members of the Poster Committee of the New York–based Art Workers Coalition (AWC). The poster pairs a photograph of the 1968 My Lai massacre with the blunt Q&A confirmation from a U.S. Army officer that children were killed by soldiers in the massacre. The work forces viewers to confront the reality of U.S. military violence and the moral consequences of the war. The poster was widely distributed and became one of the most iconic examples of political art and activist graphic design of the Vietnam War era

Title: Metalwork, Mining the Museum
Creator: Fred Wilson
Location: Maryland Center for History and Culture
Description: Mining the Museum is a groundbreaking installation by American conceptual artist Fred Wilson that was first shown at the Maryland Historical Society in Baltimore from April 4, 1992, to February 28, 1993. Wilson utilized the collection to intervene in their conventional display and confront institutional narratives around history, culture and race—particularly the histories of African Americans and Native Americans.

Title: Untitled (Your body is a battleground)
Creator: Barbara Kruger
Description: Barbara Kruger created one of the most iconic feminist artworks for the 1989 women's march on Washington in support of reproductive rights. This was in response to the political efforts that threatened the landmark U.S. Supreme court decision protecting bodily autonomy.

Title: SILENCE=DEATH
Creator: Avram Finkelstein, Brian Howard, Oliver Johnston, Charles Kreloff, Chris Li
Creditline: © 1987 The Silence = Death Project. Used by permission by ACT-UP, The AIDS Coalition To Unleash Power
Description: In 1987, artists Avram Finkelstein, Brian Howard, Oliver Johnston, Charles Kreloff, Chris Lione, and Jorge Socarrás created the iconic SILENCE=DEATH featuring the pink symbol referencing Nazi persecution of LGBTQ. The symbol was adopted by the direct action advocacy group ACT UP in their fight against the AIDS pandemic,

Title: Kissing Doesn’t Kill: Greed and Indifference Do
Creator: Gran Fury
Creditline: Gift of Lucinda and David Pollack, 2020
Description: Gran Fury, a New York-based AIDS activist artist collective (1988–1994) that emerged from ACT UP created this landmark artwork employed in bold 1980s visual campaigns. The famous image of diverse couples kissing, confronts homophobia, racism, government inaction, and corporate greed during the HIV/AIDS crisis, reframing intimacy as harmless while exposing indifference and profit-driven policies as deadly. The image was dispersed through postcards and posters featured on public buses running in major US cities.

Title: National Covid Memorial Wall
Creator: Friends of the Wall
Visualtags: Covid pandemic, memorial, collective memory, collective mourning
Description: A public memorial along the River Thames in London, made up of hundreds of thousands of hand-painted hearts—each representing a life lost to COVID-19 in the UK. Created by bereaved families and volunteers, it serves as a place of remembrance, collective mourning, while also representing a grassroots response to government mismanagement of the crisis that led to preventable deaths.

Title: George Floyd and the Anti-Racist Archive
Creator: Anonymous
Description: Urban Art Mapping is a collaborative project across disciplines that archives street art in various forms such as graffitti, tags, stickers, throw-ups, wheat pastes, murals, and projections. Their collections include works supporting the racial justice movement following George Floyd's killing.

Title: Youth Activist Art Archive (YAAA)
Creator: YAAA artists
Visualtags: Geroge Floyd, BLM, immigration, LGBTQIA, environment, racial justice, gender, health
Description: YAAA is a growing art collection created by young artists that addresses a range of social issues, from racial injustice to immigration. Artists aged 26 and younger may submit artwork for inclusion in the archive. Submissions are reviewed and curated by the YAAA team (students and faculty) at the University of Utah.

Title: United States of Attica
Creator: Faith Ringgold
Description: A politcal poster is the artist's response to the police action killing 39 people at the Attica Correctional facility when inmates took hostages to protest prison conditions. The poster features a map rendered in the pan-African flag colors with handwritten entires of other American atrocities including  anti-Chinese riots in Oregon in the 1880s, the Trail of Tears in Oklahoma that killed some 4,000 Cherokee Indians, the lynching of Emmett Till in Mississippi, the 1968 assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Tennessee, riots in California, Michigan and Texas.

Title: Robert E. Lee Statue
Creator: Dustin Klein, Alex Criqui
Description: The artists recontextulaized the conferederate monument by projecting images of Black people killed by police,  including Floyd, Breonna Taylor and Marcus-David Peters, historical figures who fought for equality, such as Harriet Tubman, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., Frederick Douglass etc on the pedestal of the Robert E. Lee statue.

Title: A Man was Lynched by Police Yesterday
Creator: Dread Scott
Visualtags: Walter Scott, NAACP, police brutality, racial justice
Description: In the 1920s-30s, the day after someone was lynched the NAACP flew the iconic flag 'A Man Was Lynched Yesterday' outsider their national headquarters in NYC. Dread Scott created an updated version of the flag in response to the police killing of Walter Scott in 2015 and the flag has since been displayed at several locations including on the facade of Jack Shainman Gallery in New York during a 2016 exhibition.

Title: On the Impossibility of Freedom in a Country Founded on Slavery and Genocide
Creator: Dread Scott
Description: In the performance, Dread Scott attempted to work forward while being repeatedly targetted by the direct force of a fire hose referencing the history of violent government action against peaceful protestors. The performance stills show Scott in the iconic hands up don't shoot gesture pointing to the ongoing struggle for racial justice.
